Situation1: The ambulance is transporting a critically ill patient through a severe thunderstorm with slick roads and low visibility.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story: The wipers thrashed against the windshield, barely keeping up with the sheets of rain. As an ambulance driver, I gripped the wheel, heart pounding, knowing the patient in the back was hanging by a thread. My training screamed at me to drive safely—no sudden moves, no speeding, especially with the roads slick and visibility near zero. But as a citizen, I was also responsible for the safety of everyone else on the road, for following emergency protocols, for not becoming another casualty in the chaos. Suddenly, alarms blared from the buildings lining the street—a flash-flood warning. Water surged at the curb, threatening to swallow the tires. I could see people waving from windows, desperate for help. My duty as a citizen pulled at me: should I stop and help, or keep going, risking everything to get my patient to the hospital? The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give.
